intro: Fraxinus excelsior var. oxyphylla, commonly known as the white ash, is a variant of the common ash tree native to Europe. It is characterized by its smooth, grey bark and opposite, compound leaves that are typically 10–20 cm long. The flowers are small and inconspicuous, arranged in pendulous catkins, and the fruit is a samara with two wings. This variety thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas. Its ecological importance includes providing habitat and food for various insects and birds.
